description.p: This is a reference for writing Lua scripts to work in Aleph One. It lists every trigger and table available to Lua scripts. It is expected that Lua functionality will grow in Aleph One, and as it does, so will this document. Not everything here is completely documented, and any help fixing that would be appreciated.
This is not a reference for Lua itself - see lua.org for that.
There are three ways to get a script to run - by embedding it in a level, by selecting a solo script in the Environment Preferences, or by selecting a script at the gather network game dialog.

To embed a script in a level, use a tool such as Atque. Use embedded Lua scripts only for map specific features, not for modifying game types. For instance, it may be tempting to embed the latest version of the Lua CTF script in a map designed only for playing CTF; however, this would prevent the user from using a later version of CTF if it were to come out, or from using another net script that works on CTF maps. Some older scenarios use Lua scripts in TEXT resources, but this is no longer recommended since they are not transmitted in net games.
To use a solo script, check the "Use Solo Script" box in Environment Preferences, and choose the script file to use.
To use a script via the network game dialog, put then script in a text file with the extension .lua. Then, at the gather network game dialog, select "use script", then select your script file.
The unit for distance we use is World Units (WU) These are the same values you’d see in Forge or with F10 location display, and 1/1024 of what A1 uses internally and what you’d see in Pfhorte.

Units for speed are . . . well let’s say they’re messy. :) Lua speeds are expressed in World Units per tick (a tick is 1/30 of a second). Forge claims to use WU per sec, but it actually uses 0.87890625 WU per sec (which equals 30 internal units per tick). The following example illustrates the various conversions:

Aleph One net games distribute a set of player inputs, which are applied to each distributed game world or to the game world in the film being played back. There is a separate copy of the Lua script running on each player’s machine. This means that in order to prevent net games from going out of sync, or films from playing back incorrectly, each of the separately running Lua scripts needs to manipulate the world the exact same way.

For example, if one player’s Lua script creates a monster, that monsters actions in the game are controlled by the random seed established at the beginning of the game. So, the other players’ scripts must create the same monster the same way, or the net game will go out of sync.

Usually this is not a problem, as long as scripters avoid functions marked with the "local player" tag, and the two local random functions, which will return different results on different machines. The global_random and random functions will return the same number on different machines, as long as they are called the same number of times, so they are safe to use for net games.
These rules apply to film playback as well; films will only play back if scripts behave exactly the same way as when the film was recorded

A few accessors, such as Ephemera and Fog were designed to be used on a "local player" basis without breaking films or net. For instance, it would be safe to programmatically disable fog when a player zooms in by checking Players.local_player.zoom_active--because the mere presence of fog will not cause a net game or film to go out of sync. Likewise, Ephemera can be created based on the Ephemera.quality setting, which will vary from machine to machine. A script that only uses Ephemera can be turned on and off and film playback will be unaffected.
When using local-safe accessors like Ephemera and Fog, it is important to use the matching random_local function, because it will not affect the progression of the ordinary random functions.
If this is confusing to you, it would be safest simply to avoid using anything marked with the "local player" tag, as well as the two local random functions and Ephemera.

A Lua script can ask for the engine to load collections it might otherwise not load; for instance, in order to be able to spawn defenders and compilers on a map that might not have them otherwise, add the indices for those collections to the global table CollectionsUsed:
Lua scripts are only active during a single level. If the user jumps to a new level, or restores from a saved game, the script is restarted in a clean state.

It is now possible to pass data across level jumps, by using the Game.restore_passed() function. This function will restore any custom fields (see the "Custom Fields" section of "Using Tables" below) in the Players or Game tables that were set immediately prior to the last level jump. Note that in order for data to survive multiple level jumps, Game.restore_passed() must be called after each level jump. Game.restore_passed() will not restore data from saved games.
It is also possible to restore data from saved games. The Game.restore_saved() function will restore all custom fields in use at the time the game was saved.
Only numbers, strings, booleans, and tables (including Aleph One’s built-in userdata tables) can be restored.

triggers.description:
These are functions scripts can define which Aleph One will call at specific times or events. For example, to regenerate health: Triggers = {} function Triggers.idle() for p in Players() do if p.life < 150 and not p.dead then p.life = p.life + 1 end end end
Calling Triggers = {} at the beginning of the script removes the compatibility triggers installed for old Lua scripts, speeding up execution of new scripts.

function.name: init
function.description: at beginning of level

argument.name: restoring_game
argument.description: true if restoring from a saved game

function.name: cleanup
function.description: at end of the level
function.note: primarily this is intended as a last chance for changing netgame scores before the postgame carnage report.

function.name: idle
function.description: at each tick, before physics and such

function.name: postidle
function.description: at each tick, after physics and such, but before rendering

function.name: start_refuel
function.description: whenever a player starts to use a refuel panel

function.name: end_refuel
function.description: whenever a player stops using a refuel panel

function.name: tag_switch
function.description: whenever a player uses a tag switch
function.note: not called when a projectile (e.g., fists) toggles a tag switch
side is only valid in version 20111201 and newer

function.name: light_switch
function.description: whenever a player uses a light switch
function.note: not called when a projectile (e.g., fists) toggles a light switch
side is only valid in version 20111201 and newer

function.name: platform_switch
function.description: whenever a player uses a platform switch

argument.name: polygon
argument.description: polygon of the platform being toggled

function.note: not called when a projectile (e.g., fists) toggles a platform switch
side is only valid in version 20111201 and newer

function.name: projectile_switch
function.description: whenever a projectile toggles a switch

function.name: terminal_enter
function.description: whenever a player starts using a terminal

function.name: terminal_exit
function.description: whenever a player stops using a terminal

function.name: pattern_buffer
function.description: whenever a player uses a pattern buffer

function.name: got_item
function.description: whenever a player picks up an item
function.note: also whenever a player gets an item when a script calls .items.add()

function.name: light_activated
function.description: whenever a light is activated or deactivated

function.name: platform_activated
function.description: whenever a platform is activated or deactivated

function.name: player_revived
function.description: whenever a player revives (presumably only happens in a netgame)

function.name: player_killed
function.description: whenever a player dies

argument.name: aggressor_player
argument.description: the player who killed player, possibly himself (suicide) (can be nil)

argument.name: action
argument.description: dying soft, dying hard, or dying flaming

argument.name: projectile
argument.description: the projectile that delivered the final blow (can be nil)

function.name: player_damaged
function.description: whenever a player has taken damage, but before he dies if applicable. The player’s suit energy or oxygen may be negative when this trigger is called; if it still is when the trigger returns, it will be set to 0. The player’s suit energy is tested again after this trigger returns, so a script may prevent a player’s death

argument.name: aggressor_player
argument.description: player who got the kill (can be nil)

argument.name: aggressor_monster
argument.description: monster that got the kill (can be nil)

argument.name: damage_amount
argument.description: the amount recently subtracted from the player. If "oxygen drain", damage_amount was assessed against player’s oxygen; otherwise against player’s suit energy

argument.name: projectile
argument.description: the projectile that delivered the damage (can be nil)

function.name: monster_damaged
function.description: whenever a monster is damaged, but before it dies if applicable. The monster’s vitality may be negative when this trigger is called. Ther monster’s vitality will be tested again after this trigger returns, so a script may prevent a monster’s death

argument.name: aggressor_monster
argument.description: the monster that caused the damage (can be nil)

argument.name: damage_amount
argument.description: the amount recently subtracted from the monster’s vitality

argument.name: projectile
argument.description: the projectile that delivered the damage (can be nil)

function.name: monster_killed
function.description: whenever a monster dies

argument.name: aggressor_player
argument.description: player who killed it (can be nil)

argument.name: projectile
argument.description: projectile that delivered the final blow (can be nil)

function.note: called after a monster has taken lethal damage, but before it’s removed from the monster list

you can use this to find out when a monster created with new_monster dies, but a monster discovered by Polygons.monsters() may have already taken lethal damage, so you may need to check for that case when using Polygons.monsters()

function.name: item_created
function.description: whenever an item is created and placed on the ground (or floating) somewhere
function.note: does not trigger on initial item placement because the initial item placement is done before Lua becomes initialised.

function.name: projectile_created
function.description: whenever a projectile is created

function.name: projectile_detonated
function.description: whenever a projectile detonates, after it has done any area of effect damage
function.note: t can be a side, polygon_floor, polygon_ceiling, monster, scenery, polygon; see Polygon:check_collision for info on how to decode. It can also be nil, in the rare case a projectile detonates without hitting something

description.p: There are numerous tables (technically, userdata) defined in Aleph One which scripts can use to access objects in the game. A complete list is below.

Unless otherwise specified, these tables are only valid inside the trigger calls listed above. Attempting to use them in the main body of a script may cause an error in this version or a future version of Aleph One.

In a real Lua table, you can set any field you want. In order to help troubleshooting, Aleph One’s userdata tables will only accept the fields listed in the documentation below. However, by prepending an underscore, custom fields can be indexed. These custom fields will be associated with the object until it is destroyed.
Each table has a read-only .index variable, that corresponds to the engine’s internal index.

Aleph One installs a set of boolean functions that can be used to recognize each of the userdata table types. For example, is_monster(Monsters[1]) returns true. Each of these functions begins with the "is_" prefix.

variable.name: polygon
variable.description: polygon this annotation is associated with
variable.note: can be nil
an annotation is only shown when its polygon is visible on the overhead map

function.name: activate
function.description: activate camera for player

function.name: clear
function.description: deletes all path points and angles

function.name: deactivate
function.description: deactivates camera

function.name: new
function.description: adds a path angle

function.name: new
function.description: adds a path point

function.name: delete
function.description: removes effect from map

function.name: play_sound
function.description: play sound coming from this effect

function.name: position
function.description: sets position of effect

function.name: deserialize
function.description: deserializes s and returns the original Lua value
function.note: see Game.serialize

function.name: global_random
function.description: returns a random number between 0 and n-1 from Aleph One’s original random number generator

variable.name: kill_limit
variable.description: the game kill limit, or 0 if there is none

variable.name: monsters_replenish
variable.description: whether monsters spawn or not; in a net game, this corresponds to the "Aliens" checkbox
variable.note: this can suppress initial monster placement, if set to false directly when the script is loaded

variable.name: proper_item_accounting
variable.description: When true, the current item counts on the map are updated properly when Lua deletes map items and changes player inventories. This defaults to false to preserve film playback with older scripts. New scripts that manipulate items should always set this to true.

variable.name: nonlocal_overlays
variable.description: When false, only the local player’s overlays are used, and only prints to the local player will be displayed. When true, the overlays and prints of whatever player is currently being viewed will apply. This defaults to false for compatibility with scripts that depend on the old behavior.

variable.name: time_remaining
variable.description: the number of ticks until the game ends, or nil if there is no time limit

variable.name: scoring_mode
variable.description: the current scoring mode (if the gametype is "custom")

variable.name: over
variable.description: Use this variable to override the game’s default scoring behavior. If set to false, the game will not end due to a score limit. If set to true, the game ends immediately. If left unset or if set to nil, the game will end if a score limit is reached. (Note that you cannot prevent the game from ending due to a time limit.)

function.name: local_random
function.description: returns a random number between 0 and n-1 from Aleph One’s original random number generator
function.note: use only for local player effects (see Net Games and Films)

function.name: random
function.description: returns a random number between 0 and n-1 using a good random number generator

function.name: random_local
function.description: returns a random number between 0 and n-1 using a good random number generator
function.note: use only for local player effects (see Net Games and Films)

function.name: restore_passed
function.description: tries to restore any Player or Game custom fields from before the last level jump; returns true if custom fields were successfully restored
function.note: if successful, overwrites all existing Player or Game custom fields

function.name: restore_saved
function.description: tries to restore any custom fields from the saved game; returns true if custom fields were successfully restored
function.note: if successful, overwrites all existing custom fields

function.name: save
function.description: saves the game (as if the user had activated a pattern buffer)
function.note: solo only

function.name: serialize
function.description: serializes v into a binary string
function.note: only numbers, strings, booleans, and tables (including Aleph One’s built-in userdata tables) can be serialized

variable.name: type
variable.description: whether the game is EMFH, KOTH, etc.

variable.name: version
variable.description: the date version of the local player’s engine
variable.note: for example, "20071103"

function.name: delete
function.description: removes item from map

function.name: play_sound
function.description: play sound coming from this item

function.name: position
function.description: sets position of item

variable.name: from_ceiling
variable.description: whether item location z is from ceiling

function.name: calculate_completion_state
function.description: returns whether level is finished, unfinished, or failed

variable.name: completed
variable.description: check this in Triggers.cleanup() to determine whether the player(s) teleported out

variable.name: extermination
variable.description: whether level has extermination flag set

variable.name: exploration
variable.description: whether level has exploration flag set

variable.name: index
variable.description: level index in the map file (starting from 0)

variable.name: repair
variable.description: whether level has repair flag set

variable.name: rescue
variable.description: whether level has rescue flag set

variable.name: retrieval
variable.description: whether level has retrieval flag set

variable.name: stash[key]
variable.description: reads/writes values to a stash shared between all running Lua scripts
variable.note: keys/values must be strings

variable.name: end_when_animation_loops
variable.description: if set, ephemera is removed once animation finishes

function.name: delete
function.description: removes ephemera from the level

function.name: position
function.description: sets position of ephemera

variable.name: rendered
variable.description: whether this ephemera was recently rendered
variable.note: you can use this to skip updating ephemera that aren’t currently visible

variable.name: shape_index
variable.note: Anvil calls this sequence

variable.name: initially_active
variable.description: whether the light was initially active

variable.name: delta_intensity
variable.description: random intensity change for this state

variable.name: delta_period
variable.description: random period change for this state

variable.name: clockwise_polygon
variable.description: polygon on clockwise side of line

variable.name: counterclockwise_polygon
variable.description: polygon on counterclockwise side of line

variable.name: decorative
variable.description: projectiles always pass the transparent sides of decorative lines

variable.name: has_transparent_side
variable.description: whether one of the line’s sides has a transparent texture

variable.name: highest_adjacent_floor
variable.description: height of higher adjacent polygon floor

variable.name: length
variable.note: this might not be accurate, if someone used Chisel’s stretch plugin

variable.name: lowest_adjacent_ceiling
variable.description: height of lower adjacent polygon ceiling

variable.name: visible_on_automap
variable.description: whether line is revealed on local player’s automap

variable.name: light
variable.description: light that controls this media’s tide

function.name: accelerate
function.description: accelerates monster

variable.name: action
variable.description: current AI action of the monster

function.name: attack
function.description: instructs monster to attack target

variable.name: blind
variable.note: only valid before monster activates

function.name: damage
function.description: damages monster
function.note: if no type is specified, fist damage is dealt

variable.name: deaf
variable.note: only valid before monster activates

function.name: delete
function.description: deletes monster

variable.name: external_velocity
variable.description: monster’s current external velocity (always in the opposite direction of facing)

variable.name: life
variable.note: monsters that haven’t spawned or teleported in yet don’t have vitality

variable.name: mode
variable.description: current AI mode of the monster

function.name: move_by_path
function.description: instructs monster to move to polygon
function.note: monsters get distracted easily en route
once it gets there, it probably won’t choose to stay

variable.name: player
variable.description: if monster is a player monster, the player; otherwise, nil

function.name: play_sound
function.description: plays sound coming from this monster

function.name: position
function.description: sets position of monster

variable.name: visible
variable.description: whether monster is visible (e.g. has teleported in)
variable.note: this has nothing to do with whether monsters are cloaked (like invisible S’pht) or not
only writable before the monster is activated

variable.name: blind
variable.description: whether monster is activated by sight

variable.name: deaf
variable.description: whether monster is activated by sound

variable.name: from_ceiling
variable.description: whether monster location z is from ceiling

variable.name: invisible
variable.description: whether monster will teleport in when activated

function.name: clear
function.description: clears the level playlist

function.name: fade
function.description: fades out the currently playing track and clears the playlist

function.name: play
function.description: appends all of the specified tracks to the end of the playlist

function.name: stop
function.description: stops level music and clears the playlist

function.name: valid
function.description: for every track passed, return true if it exists and is playable and false otherwise

variable.name: activates_adjacent_platforms_at_each_level
variable.description: platform will activate adjacent platforms at each elevation it comes to (ie.,at floor level and ceiling level)

variable.name: activates_adjacent_platforms_when_activating
variable.description: when activating, this platform activates adjacent platforms

variable.name: activates_adjacent_platforms_when_deactivating
variable.description: when deactivating, this platform activates adjacent platforms

variable.name: activates_light
variable.description: activates floor and ceiling lightsources while activating

variable.name: activates_only_once
variable.description: cannot be activated a second time

variable.name: cannot_be_externally_deactivated
variable.description: when active, can only be deactivated by itself

variable.name: contracting
variable.description: direction platform is moving or will move when active

variable.name: contracts_slower
variable.description: will move slower when contracting than when extending

variable.name: deactivates_adjacent_platforms_when_activating
variable.description: when activating, this platform deactivates adjacent platforms

variable.name: deactivates_adjacent_platforms_when_deactivating
variable.description: when deactivating, this platform deactivates adjacent platforms

variable.name: deactivates_at_each_level
variable.description: this platform will deactivate each time it reaches a discrete level

variable.name: deactivates_at_initial_level
variable.description: this platform will deactivate upon returning to its initial position

variable.name: deactivates_light
variable.description: deactivates floor and ceiling lightsources while deactivating

variable.name: delays_before_activation
variable.description: whether or not the platform begins with the maximum delay before moving

variable.name: does_not_activate_parent
variable.description: does not reactive its parent (the platform which activated it)

variable.name: extending
variable.description: direction platform is moving or will move when active

variable.name: extends_floor_to_ceiling
variable.description: there is no empty space when the platform is fully extended

variable.name: has_been_activated
variable.description: in case platform can only be activated once

variable.name: initially_extended
variable.description: high for floor platforms, low for ceiling platforms, closed for two-way platforms

variable.name: locked
variable.note: this flag doesn’t actually do anything

variable.name: monster_controllable
variable.description: whether platform can be controlled by monsters

variable.name: player_controllable
variable.description: whether platform can be controlled by players

variable.name: secret
variable.note: secret platforms aren’t shown on the overhead map

variable.name: type
variable.note: the only thing the engine uses type for is the platform’s sound

variable.name: uses_native_polygon_heights
variable.description: uses native polygon heights during automatic min,max calculation

function.name: accelerate
function.description: accelerates player

subtable.name: action_flags
subtable.note: only valid when read/written in idle()
disabled when the player is viewing a terminal
latched action flags are only true the first tick the key is held down

variable.name: action_trigger
variable.note: latched

variable.name: cycle_weapons_forward
variable.note: latched

variable.name: cycle_weapons_backward
variable.note: latched

variable.name: microphone_button
variable.note: can not be set to true; can be set to false

variable.name: toggle_map
variable.note: latched

function.name: activate_terminal
function.description: activates terminal

variable.name: color
variable.description: color of player (shirt color, if teams are enabled)

function.name: all_off
function.description: turns all compass quadrants off, disables beacon

function.name: all_on
function.description: turns all compass quadrants on, disables beacon

variable.name: lua
variable.description: whether Lua is controlling the compass

variable.name: ne
variable.description: whether north east compass quadrant is active

variable.name: nw
variable.description: whether north west compass quadrant is active

variable.name: se
variable.description: whether south east compass quadrant is active

variable.name: sw
variable.description: whether south west compass quadrant is active

variable.name: active
variable.note: if you wish to stop the user from toggling the crosshairs, you must set the state every tick

function.name: damage
function.description: inflicts damage on player

argument.name: type
argument.description: if unspecified, crush damage is delt

variable.name: direction
variable.note: this is the direction in which this player will run; for their aim, use .head_direction

variable.name: disconnected
variable.description: whether player dropped out of the game

variable.name: energy
variable.description: amount of suit energy player has (150 is normal red health)

variable.name: elevation
variable.description: angle player is looking up or down

variable.name: feet_below_media
variable.description: whether player is standing in liquid

function.name: fade_screen
function.description: fades player’s screen

function.name: find_action_key_target
function.description: if player is in range of a platform or control panel, returns a platform or side; otherwise returns nil
function.note: you can check the type of the return with is_polygon() and is_side()

function.name: find_target
function.description: returns t, x, y, z, polygon, where t is the side, polygon_floor, polygon_ceiling, monster, scenery, or polygon (if the target is the surface of a liquid) the player is looking at; and x, y, z, and polygon are the point the player is looking at
function.note: you can check the type of t with is_side(), is_polygon_floor(), is_polygon_ceiling(), is_monster(), is_scenery(), and is_polygon()

variable.name: head_below_media
variable.description: whether player is completely below liquid

variable.name: head_direction
variable.description: direction in which player is looking
variable.note: while glancing, this differs from .direction

variable.name: hotkey
variable.note: only valid when read/written in idle()
hotkeys aren’t latched, and can only be transmitted every 3 ticks
to check for a continously pressed hotkey, or to implement your own latch, count down from 2 before checking it again
hotkeys override cycle weapon backward/forward; these flags will be false for 3 ticks after a hotkey is pressed
variable.description: pressed hotkey, from 1-12, or 0 for no hotkey

subtable-accessor.name: hotkey_bindings
subtable-accessor.description: keys or buttons the player has bound to hotkeys 1-12

variable.name: invisibility_duration
variable.note: player will become subtly invisible if this is set higher than the standard invisibility duration (70 seconds)

function-variable.name: items
function-variable.description: how many of item the player is carrying

variable.name: local_
variable.description: true if this player is the local player
variable.note: normally, you shouldn’t need this--you’ll just make the game go out of sync

variable.name: motion_sensor_active
variable.description: whether player can view his motion sensor
variable.note: currently, this also controls compass visibility

variable.name: oxygen
variable.description: amount of oxygen player has (max is 10800)

function.name: clear
function.description: turns off overlay

function.name: fill_icon
function.description: fills icon with solid color

function.name: play_sound
function.description: plays sound that only player can hear
function.note: if you want all players to hear the sound as if it is coming from this player, use .monster:play_sound() instead

variable.name: polygon
variable.description: polygon the player is standing on
variable.note: if this gives you trouble, try .monster.polygon

function.name: position
function.description: set player position

function.name: print
function.description: prints message to player’s screen

function.name: revive
function.description: revives player
function.note: player must be totally dead

function.name: teleport
function.description: teleports player to polygon

function.name: teleport_to_level
function.description: teleports player to level (of course, all the other players will also go to that level)

subtable.name: texture_palette
subtable.description: displays a texture palette instead of the classic HUD

variable.name: highlight
variable.note: can be nil

variable.name: size
variable.description: how many slots the palette has
variable.note: there is a maximum of 256 slots
the texture palette is visible whenever the size is greater than 0
rows/columns may change in the future based on the user’s screen layout prefs

variable.name: type
variable.description: texture type of this slot such as wall or sprite; see "Texture Types"

function.name: clear
function.description: makes this slot empty

variable.name: totally_dead
variable.description: the player is dead and the death animation has finished

function.name: view_player
function.description: switch to another player’s view

variable.name: viewed_player
variable.description: the player currently being viewed by the local player

variable.name: current
variable.description: weapon the player is currently wielding
variable.note: can be nil

variable.name: desired
variable.description: weapon the player wants to switch to
variable.note: can be nil

variable.name: active
variable.description: when a player’s weapons are not active, he does not see weapons in hand, and can not fire

variable.name: rounds
variable.description: how many rounds are currently loaded into the weapon

function.name: select
function.description: attempts to force player to ready weapon

variable.name: weapons.current
variable.description: weapon the player is currently wielding
variable.note: can be nil

variable.name: zoom_active
variable.description: whether player’s sniper zoom is active

variable.name: from_ceiling
variable.description: whether player starting location z is from ceiling

variable.name: polygon
variable.description: polygon player starting location is in

variable.name: team
variable.description: which team starts at this player starting location

subtable-accessor.name: adjacent_polygons
subtable-accessor.description: returns adjacent polygon n (across from line n), if one exists, or nil

function.name: adjacent_polygons
function.description: iterates through all polygons directly adjacent to this polygon

function.name: change_height
function.description: changes polygon floor and ceiling heights, if possible
function.note: won’t squish monsters; returns false instead
this is much less optimized than moving a platform
you may need to create sides if you are raising/lowering what used to be a flat floor/ceiling

function.name: check_collision
function.description: returns t, x, y, z, polygon, where t is nil (if there was no collision), or the side, polygon_floor, polygon_ceiling, monster, scenery, or polygon (if the collision is with the surface of a liquid) where the line segment collided with the map (or object or media); and x, y, z, polygon is the location of the collision, or the end point if there was no collision
function.note: the owner is a monster or player to ignore, or nil
you can check the type of t with is_side(), is_polygon_floor(), is_polygon_ceiling(), is_monster(), is_scenery(), and is_polygon()
in order of descending speed: find_polygon(), check_collision() without objects, check_collision() including objects

function.name: contains
function.description: whether the point is in this polygon

function.name: endpoints
function.description: iterates through all of this polygon’s endpoints

function.name: find_polygon
function.description: traverses map from (x1, y1) and returns polygon containing (x2, y2)
function.note: can be nil if there is no direct route between the two points, or the destination point is not in any polygon
ignores floor/ceiling height

function.name: find_line_crossed_leaving
function.description: returns the polygon line crossed by line segment (x1, y1) (x2, y2)
function.note: can be nil if the line segment doesn’t intersect a polygon line

function.name: lines
function.description: iterates through all of this polygon’s lines

function.name: monsters
function.description: iterates through all monsters in this polygon (including player monsters)

variable.name: permutation
variable.description: raw permutation index of this polygon

function.name: play_sound
function.description: plays sound in center of polygon on floor

function.name: play_sound
function.description: plays sound at location
function.note: if you want to play a sound at an object location, use that object’s play_sound function instead

subtable-accessor.name: sides
subtable-accessor.description: returns polygon side n if it exists

function.name: sides
function.description: iterates through all of this polygon’s sides

variable.name: visible_on_automap
variable.description: whether polygon is revealed on local player’s automap

function.name: delete
function.description: removes projectile from the map

variable.name: damage_scale
variable.description: amount to scale projectile’s normal damage by upon detonating

function.name: play_sound
function.description: plays sound coming from this projectile

function.name: position
function.description: sets projectile position

variable.name: owner
variable.description: monster that fired projectile, or nil

variable.name: target
variable.description: target of guided projectile, or nil

function.name: damage
function.description: damages scenery

variable.name: damaged
variable.description: whether this scenery has been damaged

function.name: delete
function.description: removes scenery from the map

function.name: play_sound
function.description: play sound coming from this scenery

function.name: position
function.description: sets position of scenery

variable.name: ambient_delta
variable.description: constant offset from calculated light intensity

subtable.name: control_panel

variable.name: light_dependent
variable.description: switch can only be activated if light > 75%

variable.name: only_toggled_by_weapons
variable.description: switch can only be toggled by weapons

subtable.note: nil if the side is not a control panel
set to true or false to create/destroy a control panel

variable.name: empty
variable.note: transparent side only
setting empty to false is a no-op; set collection and texture_index instead

function.name: play_sound
function.description: play sound coming from this side

variable.name: line
variable.description: line this side is attached to

variable.name: polygon
variable.description: polygon this side is attached to

function.name: recalculate_type
function.description: correct the side type (Forge can generate incorrect side types)

variable.name: from_ceiling
variable.description: whether sound object location z is from ceiling

variable.name: light
variable.description: if sound object uses a light for volume, the light it uses
variable.note: can be nil if sound object doesn’t use light for volume

variable.name: on_platform
variable.description: whether sound object is a platform sound

variable.name: volume
variable.description: volume of sound object from 0.0 to 1.0
variable.note: can be nil if sound object uses light for volume

length.description: number of map annotations

call.description: iterates through all annotations

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new annotation

length.description: number of cameras

call.description: iterates through all cameras

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new uninitialized camera
function.note: make sure to add path points and angles before activating the camera

length.description: maximum number of effects

call.description: iterates through all valid effects

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new effect

length.description: number of endpoints in level

call.description: iterates through all endpoints in the level

description.p: Ephemera are a render-only version of Effects. They were designed to be a lightweight way to add effects such as precipitation or decals. They do not use any global random functionality, and they don’t interact at all with other objects in the world, so they are safe to turn on and off without affecting net game sync and film playback (see "Net Games and Films").

Ephemera are not saved or restored in saved games, so it is up to the Lua script to serialize them and persist them if desired; and to recreate them upon resume. Likewise, ephemera custom fields are not saved/restored using Level.restored_saved()
All ephemera functions are "local player"

length.description: maximum number of ephemera

call.description: iterates through all valid ephemera

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new ephemera

variable.name: quality
variable.note: it is up to the script’s discretion how many ephemera to create / maintain, based on this quality setting; if set to off, ephemera are not rendered regardless of how many the script creates

length.description: number of saved map objects (of all types)

call.description: iterates through all goals

length.description: maximum number of map objects

call.description: iterates through all valid items

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new item

length.description: number of map objects in the level

call.description: iterates through all item starting locations in the level

length.description: number of lines in level

call.description: iterates through all lines in the level

length.description: number of lights in level

call.description: iterates through all lights in the level

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new light

length.description: number of media (liquids) on the level

call.description: iterates through all media on the level

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new liquid

length.description: maximum number of monsters

call.description: iterates through all valid monsters (including player monsters)

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new monster

length.description: number of map objects in the level

call.description: iterates through all monster starting locations in the level

length.description: number of platforms on the level

call.description: iterates through all platforms in the level

length.description: number of players in the game

call.description: iterates through all players in the game

function.name: print
function.description: prints message to all players’ screens

variable.name: local_player
variable.note: normally, you shouldn’t need this--you’ll just make the game go out of sync

length.description: number of map objects in the level

call.description: iterates through all player starting locations in the level

length.description: number of polygons in the level

call.description: iterates through all polygons in the level

length.description: maximum number of projectiles

call.description: iterates through all valid projectiles

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new projectile
function.note: remember to set the projectile’s elevation, facing and owner immediately after you’ve created it

length.description: maximum number of map objects

call.description: iterates through all valid scenery

function.name: new
function.description: returns a new scenery

length.description: number of sides on the level

call.description: iterates through all sides on the level

function.name: new
function.description: creates a new side
function.note: side must not already exist

length.description: number of map objects in the level

call.description: iterates through all sound objects in the level

length.description: number of terminal texts in the level

call.description: iterates through all terminal texts on the level

variable.name: active_texture_index
variable.description: bitmap index when control panel is active

variable.name: class
variable.description: class of this control panel type

variable.name: collection
variable.description: collection this control panel belongs to

variable.name: inactive_texture_index
variable.description: bitmap index when control panel is inactive/destroyed

mnemonic.name: kill the man with the ball

variable.name: initial_count
variable.description: how many items of this type are placed in the level during initial placement

variable.name: maximum_count
variable.description: maximum number of this type of item in the level and in player inventories

variable.name: maximum_inventory
variable.description: maximum number of this type of item players can carry

variable.name: minimum_count
variable.description: minimum number of this type of item in the level and in player inventories

variable.name: random_chance
variable.description: chance from 0 to 1.0 this item will appear in a respawn period

variable.name: random_location
variable.description: whether items of this type spawn in random locations

variable.name: total_available
variable.description: total number of items of this type that can be spawned in this level
variable.note: -1 means infinite items are available
setting this to anything but -1 will only be effective if changed immediately when the script runs, before item placement is done

variable.name: attacks_immediately
variable.description: monster will try an attack immediately

variable.name: cannot_be_dropped
variable.description: monster cannot be skipped during placement

function-variable.name: enemies
function-variable.description: whether monster class is an enemy

function-variable.name: friends
function-variable.description: whether monster class is a friend

variable.name: impact_effect
variable.description: type of effect generated when monster gets hit by a bleeding projectile

function-variable.name: immunities
function-variable.description: whether monster type is immune to damage type

variable.name: initial_count
variable.description: how many monsters of this type are placed in the level during initial placement

variable.name: item
variable.description: type of item the monster drops when it dies

variable.name: maximum_count
variable.description: maximum number of this type of monster in the level

variable.name: minimum_count
variable.description: minimum number of this type of monster in the level

variable.name: melee_impact_effect
variable.description: type of effect generated when monster gets hit by a melee projectile

variable.name: random_chance
variable.description: chance from 0 to 1.0 this monster will appear in a respawn period

variable.name: random_location
variable.description: whether monsters of this type spawn in random locations

variable.name: total_available
variable.description: total number of monsters of this type that can be spawned in this level
variable.note: -1 means infinite monsters are available
setting this to anything but -1 will only be effective if changed immediately when the script runs, before monster placement is done

function-variable.name: weaknesses
function-variable.description: whether monster type has a weakness to damage type

variable.name: waits_with_clear_shot
variable.description: monster will sit and fire if he has a clear shot

types.description: The string mnemonics listed below can be used for assignment and as arguments to functions. Additionally, Aleph One’s Lua interpreter has been modified so that equality comparisons between userdata types and strings are possible.

For example, this script would move all players on the blue team to the red team: for p in Players() do if p.team == "blue" then p.team = "red" end end And this one would damage all major compilers with 10 points of fusion damage: for m in Monsters() do if m.type == "major compiler" then m:damage(10, "fusion") end end Each type has a read-only .index field, which represents the game’s internal index: > =ItemTypes["pistol"].index 1
Each type also has a .mnemonic field, which is handy for finding the mnemonic of a given type: > =MonsterTypes["major compiler"].class.mnemonic compiler
You can even use the mnemonic field to customize the mnemonics for your scenario. Note that you can only have one string mnemonic per type index: > WeaponTypes["fist"].mnemonic = "puncher" > =WeaponTypes["puncher"].index 0 > =WeaponTypes["fist"] nil
If you do this, you should customize them all at the beginning of the script. Changing mnemonics mid-game will confuse anyone who tries to read your script, and probably yourself as well!

description.pre:
--[[ This is an example of an icon in the format used by Aleph One’s overlay functions. The first characters are a digit string describing the number of colors. (in this example, it’s 7. The first character that is not a digit is ignored, as are all the characters following it that are the same character. (i.e. I could use a q instead of a newline here. Then, for every color, it reads a character, followed by a six-digit hex string, which is the HTML-style color corresponding to that character in the image. After reading this string, it ignores the next character, whatever it is. Once it has read every color, it reads all the following characters, and for every character it reads for which a color has defined, it puts that color into the icon as the next pixel. Other characters are ignored. (see below.) Icons are always 16x16. ]]
[[ 7 0000FF #000000 .FFFFFF $7FAE20 %EBD52A ,45983C *5B4714 *************# The fact *************# that it *$$$#*********# ignores $$$$$#********# characters $$$$$#$$******# that $$##$##$$*****# are $$$$##.#$$#**# not colors $%%$$#.,#$#**# can be %%%%%%##,#$$# exploited to interesting %%%%%%%##$$# effect by a sufficiently #%%%%%%%$$$$# resourceful and obnoxious *##%%%%%%$$$$### #**#%%#%%%###**# *#*##%%#%%$$$$# person **# #%%##%$$# such as **# #%%%#%$# myself :) Additionally, once it has read 256 valid characters, it ignores the rest of the string. ]]
